news_summary: Advancements in laser technology have enabled scientists to heat solid gold to unprecedented temperatures, showcasing remarkable progress in high-energy material research.
news_summary_fr: Les progrès de la technologie laser ont permis aux scientifiques de chauffer de l'or solide à des températures sans précédent, ce qui constitue un progrès remarquable dans la recherche sur les matériaux à haute énergie.
news_summary_es: Los avances en la tecnología láser han permitido a los científicos calentar oro sólido a temperaturas sin precedentes, mostrando un notable progreso en la investigación de materiales de alta energía.

articles.title: Giant laser heats solid gold to 14 times its melting point
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 23 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02344-wA 50 nm thick sheet of solid gold was heated well beyond a theoretical limit, suggests new study — plus, what researchers think about the threat of nuclear war.
articles.content:
A 50 nm thick sheet of solid gold was heated well beyond a theoretical limit, suggests new study — plus, what researchers think about the threat of nuclear war.

You have full access to this article via your institution.

Download the Nature Podcast 23 July 2025

In this episode:

00:46 How hot can solid gold get?

A new study suggests that gold can be superheated far beyond its melting point without it becoming a liquid. Using an intense burst from a laser, a team heated a gold foil to 14 times its melting point, far beyond a theoretical limit put forward in previous studies. The team suggest that the speed at which they heated the gold allowed them to shoot past this limit, but there is scepticism about whether the team actually achieved the level of heating they report.

Research Article: White et al.

News and Views: Solid gold superheated to 14 times its melting temperature

10:05 Research Highlights

How island life led to huge wingspans for flying foxes, and how a sugary diet ‘rewires’ a mouse’s brain.

Research Highlight: How the world’s biggest bats got their enormous wingspans

Research Highlight: How sugar overload in early life affects the brain later

12:30 Researchers warn about the threat of nuclear war

With increasing political polarisation and more nuclear-armed nations, researchers are warning about the threat of nuclear war. Reporter Alex Witze has been speaking to scientists, and she told us about their chief concerns and how to avoid a conflict in an era of AI and misinformation.

News Feature: How to avoid nuclear war in an era of AI and misinformation

23:22 Briefing Chat

What a new AI model from China means for science, and why some dolphins use sponges to hunt.

Nature: ‘Another DeepSeek moment’: Chinese AI model Kimi K2 stirs excitement

Associated Press: Some Australian dolphins use sponges to hunt fish, but it’s harder than it looks

Subscribe to Nature Briefing, an unmissable daily round-up of science news, opinion and analysis free in your inbox every weekday.

Never miss an episode. Subscribe to the Nature Podcast on Apple Podcasts, Spotify, YouTube Music or your favourite podcast app. An RSS feed for the Nature Podcast is available too.
articles.reasoning: The article describes a scientific breakthrough involving heating gold beyond theoretical limits, which represents progress in materials science and technology. While it does not directly mention immediate practical applications, such advances often contribute to future technological innovations. The inclusion of researchers' thoughts on nuclear war adds a serious tone but does not overshadow the positive scientific achievement.
articles.personality_title: Scientists superheat solid gold to record-breaking temperatures
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Researchers have long studied how materials react under extreme heat. Gold, known for its melting point, was believed to turn liquid once heated past a certain temperature.

**What happened**
A group of scientists used a giant laser to heat a super-thin sheet of solid gold—just 50 nanometers thick—to an incredible 14 times its melting point. Amazingly, the gold stayed solid instead of melting into a liquid.

**Impact**
This discovery challenges previous ideas about how metals behave under extreme heat. Understanding these new properties could lead to advances in materials science, helping develop stronger, more heat-resistant materials for future technology.

**What's next step**
Researchers plan to explore how other materials respond to similar superheating and investigate potential practical uses of this discovery, such as improving electronics or manufacturing processes.

**One-sentence takeaway**
By superheating solid gold beyond its known limits, scientists open doors to exciting new possibilities in material science and technology.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des scientifiques surchauffent de l'or solide à des températures record
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Les chercheurs étudient depuis longtemps comment les matériaux réagissent sous des chaleurs extrêmes. L'or, connu pour son point de fusion, était censé fondre une fois chauffé au-delà d'une certaine température.

**Ce qui s'est passé**
Une équipe de scientifiques a utilisé un laser géant pour chauffer une fine feuille d'or solide de seulement 50 nanomètres d'épaisseur à une température incroyable 14 fois supérieure à son point de fusion. Étonnamment, l'or est resté solide au lieu de fondre.

**Impact**
Cette découverte remet en question les idées précédentes sur le comportement des métaux sous des chaleurs extrêmes. Comprendre ces nouvelles propriétés pourrait aider à développer des matériaux plus solides et résistants à la chaleur pour les technologies futures.

**Prochaine étape**
Les chercheurs prévoient d'étudier comment d'autres matériaux réagissent à des surchauffes similaires et d'explorer les applications pratiques de cette découverte, comme l'amélioration de l'électronique ou des procédés de fabrication.

**Leçon en une phrase**
En surchauffant de l'or solide au-delà de ses limites connues, les scientifiques ouvrent la voie à de nouvelles possibilités passionnantes en science des matériaux et technologie.
articles.personality_title_es: Científicos sobrecalient oro sólido a temperaturas récord
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Los investigadores han estudiado durante mucho tiempo cómo reaccionan los materiales bajo calor extremo. Se creía que el oro, conocido por su punto de fusión, se volvería líquido al superar cierta temperatura.

**Qué pasó**
Un equipo de científicos usó un láser gigante para calentar una delgada lámina de oro sólido, de solo 50 nanómetros de espesor, a una temperatura increíble de 14 veces su punto de fusión. Sorprendentemente, el oro permaneció sólido en lugar de fundirse.

**Impacto**
Este descubrimiento desafía ideas previas sobre cómo se comportan los metales bajo calor extremo. Comprender estas nuevas propiedades podría ayudar a desarrollar materiales más fuertes y resistentes al calor para tecnologías futuras.

**Próximo paso**
Los investigadores planean estudiar cómo otros materiales responden a un sobrecalentamiento similar y explorar posibles usos prácticos de este hallazgo, como mejorar la electrónica o procesos de fabricación.

**Conclusión en una frase**
Al sobrecalentar oro sólido más allá de sus límites conocidos, los científicos abren nuevas y emocionantes posibilidades en la ciencia de materiales y tecnología.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed painting of a delicate, glowing gold foil sheet radiating intense heat waves as it floats above a smooth, dark surface, surrounded by abstract swirling light beams symbolizing a powerful laser burst, all rendered in warm golds, soft reds, and gentle oranges against a subdued natural background.
